awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding Migration and Fertility
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates the question of whether migrant women's fertility reflects high desired family sizes or difficulties regulating fertility due to high cost, lack of knowledge about services, and other obstacles.  Society's most vulnerable women often face great challenges with fertility regulation.  This may be particularly true of international migrant women who often lack healthcare access, social networks, and/or financial resources that might be important for fertility regulation.  In this study, the association between migration and fertility, family planning use, fertility preferences, and difficulties regulating fertility is investigated by comparing international migrants to women in their countries of origin who have similar background characteristics but did not migrate.  Findings will expand knowledge concerning population change and will have the potential to inform outreach strategies and public health campaigns that reduce unintended outcomes. 

This project explores the association between international migration and fertility by combining data from both sending and receiving countries using a propensity score matching approach. To date, most studies have been limited to the use of data sources collected primarily in receiving countries and have typically compared migrants to native-born residents of the receiving country, rather than to residents of their country of origin with whom they share a common background. In contrast, our project integrates cross-sectional data from two surveys to create a novel data set that allows for matching highly similar respondents who did and did not migrate from sending countries to a receiving country. This enables: (1) investigation of the association between international migration and fertility by comparing migrants in receiving countries to similar non-migrants in sending countries; and (2) exploration of the association between international migration and underlying reproductive desires and behaviors that could help explain why migration is associated with fertility.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
"Collaborative Research: Migration and Fertility," led by Drs. Julia Behrman (Northwestern University) and Abigail Weitzman (University of Texas at Austin), seeks to uncover the complex relationship between migration and fertility. The overall premise is that international migration is likely to have multiple effects on women's reproductive processes. For instance, when women migrate, they become exposed to new social norms about ideal family size and contraceptive use. At the same time, they may come into contact with new information about different methods of contraception and how these methods work; have greater (or less) access to reproductive healthcare; and experience different economic circumstances the enable (or impede) contraceptive use relative to when they were living in their countries of origin.

To explore these various possibilities, we simultaneously compare international migrants to women in their countries of origin who have similar backgrounds but did not migrate and to non-migrant women who live in their destination context. Through this multi-sited analysis of reproductive-aged women, we find that although African migrants have significantly higher numbers of children than do native French women (an average of 1.85 versus 1.32 children), they have significantly smaller numbers of children than do women who still reside in their African countries of origin (an average of 1.85 versus 3.35 children). These differences grow even more pronounced when looking specifically at women who are toward the end of their reproductive years, around ages 40 to 49. Among these women, African migrants are predicted to have 2.52 children, which is still greater than the predicted 1.98 children among native French women but substantially smaller than the predicted 6.27 children among women in corresponding African countries.

Further analyses indicate that these patterns are largely attributable to differences in contraceptive use. In other words, the types of contraception that African migrants use closely resemble the types of contraception that French women use in France—much more so than the types of contraception that women use in corresponding African sending countries. We find similar patterns of contraceptive use when comparing Turkish migrants in France to native French women and to Turkish women in Tukey. Thus, it is most likely the case that, once in France, migrant women have greater information about and access to contraception via improved access to reproductive healthcare and/or economic capacity. On the whole, these findings underscore the importance of making highly effective and culturally appropriate forms of contraception widely available to migrant women.

These findings also have notable implications for scholars and policymakers who are interested in the relationship between migration and fertility. Namely, they highlight the types of insights that are gained by taking a multi-sited, comparative approach rather than singularly focusing on migrant women in destination contexts. Conclusions drawn from the latter approach—which is the currently the predominant approach—can have real-world policy implications. For instance, comparisons of migrant and non-migrant women’s pregnancy rates have previously been proposed as a metric for assessing the degree of migrant incorporation into French society. This project’s findings underscore the need to further compare migrant women to women who remain in their countries of origin before drawing conclusions about migrant integration and/or adaptation.

 


Last Modified: 09/14/2023
Modified by: Abigail Weitzman
